There are three kinds of suffering as results, or it is said there are eight.
The three are the suffering of formations, the suffering of suffering, and the suffering of change.

The eight are the suffering of birth, the suffering of old age, the suffering of sickness, the suffering of death, the suffering of being united with what is disliked, the suffering of separation from what is loved, the suffering of not obtaining what one seeks, and the suffering of the five appropriated aggregates in brief.
The suffering of birth has two causes:
First, being oppressed by various sufferings; second, being the basis for other sufferings.
That is to say, in the womb between the stomach and intestines, one fully experiences the suffering of being oppressed by various extremely impure substances.
When first emerging from the womb, one again experiences the great suffering of the limbs being squeezed.
Because there is birth, various sufferings such as old age, sickness, and death follow.
The suffering of old age is the suffering of the change and decay of time.
The suffering of sickness is the suffering of the change and transformation of the great elements.
The suffering of death is the suffering of the change and decay of life.
The remaining sufferings can be understood.
Each should be known according to the ancient explanations.
Truth means true meaning.
Suffering is truly suffering, and there is no other suffering, so it is called truth.
Ordinary people do not know it, only the sages recognize it.
It is the truth of the sages, so it is called the noble truth.
Accumulation means the meaning of cause. It refers to afflictions and karma that can accumulate and produce suffering.
Suffering subsumes the contaminated, while the cause excludes the effect of suffering.
Cessation refers to cessation through discernment, which is precisely nirvÄá¹‡a. There are four kinds of this.
The path refers to the noble path, which has the meaning of a thoroughfare and a passage. It is precisely the uncontaminated conditioned activities of the noble ones.
The first two are contaminated, while the latter two are uncontaminated.
The essence of these four wondrous principles is one true suchness. Due to the distinctions in the interpretations based on them, they are divided into four kinds. Therefore, their nature is pure.

The praise says:
That which is able to directly manifest the essence and give rise to and nurture all dharmas is called a cause. Since the cause is a condition, it is called a causal condition.
A condition refers to relying on conditions. The four conditions are generally referred to as conditions.
Excluding the fruit of Buddhahood, the seven consciousnesses in the causal stage, the seen and seen-as parts, etc. that are able to perfume seeds are called causal conditions.
Seeds of the same species that produce each other and produce actual dharmas in all states are called conditions as cause, because they all directly create the substance of the effect.
The condition as immediate antecedent is the same class of consciousness and its activities, the former giving way to the latter.
Same has two meanings.
The first is similarity, sameness.
For example, in the case of mental activities, the former is also one feeling and the latter is also one feeling, because the substance is the same, it is called similar.
The second is equal power, which is called the same.

Either the one dharma of the former moment is the same as the condition as immediate antecedent for the one dharma of the latter moment, or the all of the former moment is able to be the condition as immediate antecedent for the one dharma of the latter moment, and therefore it is called the condition as immediate antecedent.
This is the meaning of opening the way.

For example, the eye consciousness of the former moment is the condition as immediate antecedent for the group of eye consciousness of the latter moment, but not for the ear consciousness, etc., or for that arising simultaneously, because the quantity is not the same.
The condition as object is an objective realm with substance that is able to produce mind and its activities and is called a condition.
The mind and so forth bear the aspect of that object, and the object to be grasped is called the object.
It has two aspects, and there is something to be distinguished.
The dominant condition means the meaning of powerful influence, because it gives rise to powerful influence.

The immediately preceding condition is only the mind and mental factors, while the object condition extends to all dharmas, because these two conditions only depend on the mind and mental factors as their effects.
The essence of the causal condition extends to all conditioned dharmas, and its effect is the same.
The essence and effect of the dominant condition both extend to all dharmas.

The commentary praises:
In these twelve links of dependent arising, ignorance takes delusion as its essence and is the affliction that gives rise to karma.
The activity of the members is the three activities of the three karmas, which are unwholesome, wholesome, and unmoving karma.
These two are both actual dharmas and seeds.
Consciousness is only the fundamental consciousness.
Name-and-form includes the five aggregates.
The six sense bases are only the six sense organs.
The two dharmas of contact and feeling are only the nature of retribution.
The five members from consciousness down are only seeds.
Craving is only the self-nature of craving for love. Grasping includes all passions as its nature.
These two are also actual dharmas and seeds.
The existence member is in essence the combination of the activity of the six members, namely, the two of craving and grasping moisten.
The six members from the present activity of the member of karmic forces down are the present arising of the future fruit. The arising of the fruit of future existence is called existence.
Existence is only seeds.ğŸ”½From the intermediate state of existence up to the state of the present existence before decay and change, the five aggregates are all called the member of birth.
From the state of decay and change up to the end of life, the five aggregates are called old age and death.

That is, due to ignorance, one creates good and evil karma that perfumes the fundamental consciousness, and along with the five dharmas such as consciousness, one experiences the results of karma. When craving and grasping join in nourishing [the karma], the first six factors are called existence because the future fruit can be produced. The process of rebirth is called birth, and the decay and death at the end of life is called death.

The meaning of the emptiness, quiescence, and purity of the perfection of giving is the meaning of the phrase bodhisattva, and the meaning of the emptiness, quiescence, and purity of morality, patience, vigor, meditation, and wisdom is the meaning of the phrase bodhisattva.
The commentary praises:
Below this, there are sixteen chapters that clarify the emptiness and quiescence of the fundamental nature of the supreme meaning dharmas, in order to reveal the meaning of the phrase bodhisattva.
Within this, there are three parts:
First, clarifying practice with six chapters; second, clarifying stages with two chapters; third, clarifying virtues with eight chapters.
There are three in the practice:
First, the practice of the six perfections in general; second, the practice of contemplating the principle; third, the practice of cultivating separately.
This is the first.
There are three kinds of giving, namely, of wealth, of the Dharma, and of fearlessness. This takes non-greed and the two actions it gives rise to as its nature.

There are three kinds of precepts, namely, precepts for restraining, precepts for embracing goodness, and precepts for benefiting sentient beings. This takes the three actions at the time of receiving the bodhisattva precepts as its nature.

There are three kinds of patience, namely, patience in enduring suffering, patience in enduring harm from others, and patience in investigating the Dharma. Here, in sequence, it takes non-hatred, vigor, careful wisdom, and the three actions they give rise to as its nature.
There are three kinds of vigor, namely, armor-like vigor, vigor in embracing goodness, and vigor in benefiting and bringing happiness.
This vigor takes diligence and the three actions it gives rise to as its essence.
There are three kinds of meditation, namely, meditation in abiding, meditation in attracting and manifesting, and meditation in accomplishing tasks.
This meditation only takes samÄdhi as its nature.
There are three kinds of prajÃ±Ä: that of the stage of added effort, that of the stage of insight, and that of the stage of cultivation.
PrajÃ±Ä of these three kinds all have discernment of dharmas as their nature.
The above explanations only discuss their natures. If we add their retinue, each has as its nature all the virtues that accompany it.
Why are these six called perfections?

Because they are embraced by seven kinds of supremacy: 1) supremacy of abode, which is the bodhisattva nature; 2) supremacy of support, which is the mind of great bodhi; 3) supremacy of attitude, which is compassion for sentient beings; 4) supremacy of activity, which is the performance of all practices; 5) supremacy of skillful means, which is embraced by the knowledge of the absence of characteristics; 6) supremacy of dedication, which is dedication to bodhi; 7) supremacy of purity, which is not mixed with the two obstacles.
Because they possess these seven meanings, they are called perfections. Otherwise, they are not.
Because of this, there are four alternatives for giving and so forth.
1) Giving that is not a perfection, because it does not possess the seven kinds of supremacy.
Second, it is not giving but pÄramitÄ, because seeing others practicing giving oneself is endowed with the seven [pÄramitÄs].
Third, it is both giving and pÄramitÄ, because practicing giving oneself is also endowed with the seven [pÄramitÄs].
Fourth, it is neither giving nor pÄramitÄ, because oneself does not practice giving, and seeing others practicing giving does not give rise to sympathetic joy.
Cultivating these six pÄramitÄs has five aspects:
First, cultivation based on support; second, cultivation based on attention; third, cultivation based on intention; fourth, cultivation based on skillful means; fifth, cultivation based on mastery.
The first, cultivation based on support, has four aspects:
First, cultivation based on causes, which refers to cultivating right practice based on the power of one's inherent nature;
Second, cultivation based on retribution, which refers to cultivating right practice based on one's superior body;
Third, cultivation based on vows, which refers to cultivating right practice based on one's original vows;
Fourth, cultivation based on the wisdom of discernment, which refers to cultivating right practice based on the wisdom of discernment.
The second, cultivation based on attention, also has four aspects:
The first is based on superior understanding, which is to generate superior understanding towards the sutras that correspond to the perfections.
The second is based on savoring, which is to deeply savor the seen excellent merits of the perfections.
The third is based on rejoicing, which is to deeply rejoice in the six perfections practiced by all sentient beings.
The fourth is based on the cultivation of intention, which is to deeply wish for the superior six perfections for oneself and others in the future.
The third, cultivation based on intention, has six aspects:

The first is the intention of non-discontent, such as the one who is not discontent with giving. This means that a bodhisattva, in a single instant, gives the seven treasures of the trichiliocosm to a single sentient being, and gives his body and life as numerous as the sands in the Ganges River. In this way, he practices giving for eons as numerous as the sands in the Ganges River. As he does for a single sentient being, he does likewise for the entire realm of sentient beings. When practicing giving in this way, he causes all of them to quickly attain accomplishment in supreme enlightenment.
Even then, the bodhisattva is still not content, and this is called the intention of non-discontent with giving.

The third is the intention of vastness, which means that the bodhisattva's mind of giving is vast and great, and he is able to give away all internal and external things without the slightest stinginess.ğŸ”½The fourth is the intention of joy, which means that the bodhisattva is joyful when giving, and the recipient is also joyful when receiving.ğŸ”½The fifth is the intention of repaying kindness, which means that the bodhisattva thinks that the recipient has great kindness towards him, because he is able to practice giving and receive the fruits of giving. The bodhisattva does not think that he has any kindness towards the recipient.

The sixth is the intention of purity, which means that the bodhisattva does not seek any rewards or future fruits when giving. He only seeks to benefit the recipient and perfect his own practice of giving.

Sixth is the good intention, that is, the bodhisattva, by means of the vast aggregate of giving cultivated, obtains the maturation of giving to all sentient beings, not for himself, and moreover, with this merit, he dedicates it to unsurpassed perfect enlightenment together with all sentient beings, called the good intention of giving.
The other five perfections are explained in detail in the Abhidharma and other texts.
Fourth is the cultivation based on skillful means, that is, by means of nondiscriminating cognition observing the three wheels to be all pure, thereby quickly accomplishing the practice.
Fifth is the cultivation based on mastery, which is threefold:
First is mastery of the body, that is, the essential body and the body of enjoyment.
Second is mastery of practice, that is, the transformation body, etc., manifesting all kinds of practices in common with sentient beings.
Third is mastery of speech, that is, expounding the six perfections in all their varieties without obstruction.
The sutra says:

Commentary:
Second, the principle and practice to be contemplated.
Before this, the twenty kinds of emptiness, etc., should be explained, because emptiness is precisely emptiness and tranquility.
Since the names are the same, they should not be established again, so they are not explained.
Although the essence of this true suchness, etc., is precisely that which is revealed by emptiness and tranquility, since the names are different, they are established separately.
Among them, the eight names have one essence.
True suchness: True means real, manifesting as not false.
Such means as usual, showing no change.
This is precisely the meaning of being still and not false. It is called true suchness by negating falsehood and manifesting permanence.
The dharma realm is so called because it is the characteristic that is the basis of the marvelous dharma of the three vehicles.
Dharma nature refers to the true fundamental essence of all dharmas.
Non-false nature refers to the nature that is free from false inversion and non-delusion.
Unchanging nature refers to the fact that it does not transform at all times.
Equality nature refers to the fact that it pervades all dharmas.

The nature of separation from arising refers to the fact that arising means arising and obstruction, like raw food and so forth. This is the nature of false and defiled dharmas, separated from the nature of arising and obstruction that is firm and strong.
Moreover, arising refers to arising and ceasing. The essence that is separated from arising and ceasing is called the nature of separation from arising.
The ultimate reality is so called because it is the object of non-inverted cognition.
Reality refers to the absence of inversion. This place is the ultimate, therefore it is called the ultimate. Because there is nothing further to seek beyond the nature of non-self.
In this text, only eight names are mentioned. There are twelve names in the first assembly, and six names in the Abhidharma and other texts.

The essence is only one suchness, with different names. It is distinguished according to what is to be countered and in accordance with the distinctions in its interpretation, thus forming many kinds.

Praise:
This is the second practice of the factors of enlightenment.
The four establishments of mindfulness are body, feelings, mind, and dharmas, with wisdom as their nature.
Wisdom abides in these four objects through mindfulness, and is called the establishment of mindfulness.
The four right efforts are: 1. The effort of restraint, which means to generate desire and exertion in order to eliminate the evil dharmas that have already arisen.
2. The effort of elimination, which means to generate desire and exertion in order to prevent the non-arising of the evil dharmas that have not yet arisen.
3. The effort of cultivation, which means to generate desire, and so forth up to directing and maintaining the mind, in order to give rise to the wholesome dharmas that have not yet arisen.
4. The effort of protection, which means to generate desire, and so forth up to directing and maintaining the mind, in order to maintain the wholesome dharmas that have already arisen.
These four kinds are all by nature effort.
Stimulating wisdom, one is able to gradually subdue, and this is called right exertion.

Because of these four, one induces samÄdhi, and therefore the four bases of supernatural power are by nature samÄdhi.

These seven are able to universally contemplate all dharmas, and for that reason they are established as being equal.
Equality means universality.
The eight members of the holy path are right views, right thought, right effort, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right mindfulness, and right concentration.
The three of speech, action, and livelihood are included in the aggregate of morality.
The remaining members are named according to their own natures and arise in the state of the path of cultivation.

The holy ones who are learners, by means of the eight members, embrace the traces of practice, the correct path, and are able to completely eliminate all the passions and are able to finally realize liberation. For this reason, these eight are called the members of the holy path.
These thirty-seven kinds of factors that contribute to awakening, in combination, have eleven dharmas as their own natures:

Eighth, lightness and comfort, which includes the branch of enlightenment of tranquility.

The sutra says:
